body: ''CHOCOLATE is the next coffee,'' confided one importer. ''Chocolate is the new olive oil,'' said a chocolatier. ''Chocolate now is where cheese was 10 years ago,'' a pastry chef asserted. title: Hints of Wine? Chocolate Enters The Tasting Room

title: City Seeks Ideas As Trash Costs Dwarf Estimate

body: A half-block of a quiet tree-lined neighborhood of immigrant families was gutted by flames yesterday morning, leaving dozens of people in Brooklyn homeless. title: Greenpoint Fire Guts Half-Block And Displaces 29 Families

body: EVERY year I am offered a seat in a pace car of the New York City Marathon. To paraphrase Mel Brooks, it's good to be the sports columnist. The 26-mile, 385-yard tour via cordoned roads invokes the same reaction every year: I pledge to get in better running shape, and I renew my love vows for my hometown. Mostly, I get hungry. My attention span
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: URBAN STUDIES/SALIVATING; 26.2 Miles of Food

title: Sports of The Times; Too Famous To Suffer Unnoticed

body: Since Georgia Heywood moved to Greenpoint, Brooklyn, two months ago, it's not unusual for her to wake up in a fright at 3 a.m. and stuff her pillow into the freezer. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT; Sleep Tight, and Don't Let... Oh, Just Forget About It

body: Stella Harmatiuk, 81, stood on the corner of Manhattan Avenue and Calyer Street in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, on a recent windy morning and smiled beatifically at the people walking down the sidewalk. Until they got close. Then she snapped into candidate mode and accosted them with a pink flier bearing her likeness. ''Hold it!'' she barked. Many obeyed.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT -- CITYPEOPLE; Finding No Shortage Of Windmills To Tilt At

body: For children of Asian descent growing up in and around New York City, cram schools are a part of life. title: Taking Lessons From Another Culture; For Students of Many Backgrounds, a Study Tool From the Far East

body: DURING the blackout of 2003, one of the few sites where looting was reported in New York was a tiny boutique for sneaker connoisseurs on the Lower East Side called Alife Rivington Club. It was a stark reminder that sneakers are among the most coveted consumer goods in America, with more than $15 billion spent on nearly 430 million pairs in 2002.
title: Sneaker Stories: Following the Trail Of a Cultural Shift

body: IN a 1981 book called ''The Meaning of Things: Domestic Symbols and the Self,'' two Chicago sociologists asked 315 people what item in their home they cherished most. title: From Found Objects, A Gothic Décor

title: 2 Couples Found Shot Dead In Separate Murder-Suicides

body: Minutes after New York City lost its power on Aug. 14, streams of raw sewage began to flow into surrounding waterways. By the time electricity was restored, 490 million gallons had spilled -- 145 million gallons from the city's largest pumping station, on the Lower East Side -- causing beaches to close and posing health and environmental hazards.
title: Sewage Spill During the Blackout Exposed a Lingering City Problem

body: The neon Domino Sugar sign looms over the East River like a beacon, visible for miles. Gleaming above the Brooklyn complex where sugar has been refined for more than a century, it has become a symbol of a rapidly fading industrial legacy, a reminder that the city known for high-tech finance and elegant living was built on ships and machinery, brawn
title: Familiar Domino Sugar Refinery Will Shut Much of Its Operation

title: Heroes, From Rappelling Officer to Sewage Savior

body: One morning last week, Zoe Klein, a 24-year-old circus performer from Brooklyn, stood practicing her act, which involved swinging a pair of tethered balls, and stared out to the Hudson River. ''Growing up in New York, I always felt boxed in,'' she said. ''I always knew we were surrounded by water, but it always felt dirty or inaccessible.''
title: Going Near the Water; Renovation Efforts Reclaim the City's Forbidden Shoreline

body: For many Internet addicts, the blackout last week was a rude reminder of just how decisively the vaunted 21st-century digital lifestyle can be laid low by a disruption in 19th-century electrons. title: The Bits Are Willing, but the Batteries Are Weak

body: Three operators of a moving company charged with effectively holding customers' possessions for ransom were convicted of fraud by a jury in federal court in Brooklyn yesterday. title: Movers Convicted of Fraud; Held Clients' Goods Hostage

title: One Verging on Stardom, One Left Back, With a Gun

body: A Yale graduate with a promising acting career was shot in the face early yesterday morning by her former fiancé, who then killed himself, the police said. title: Ex-Fiancé Shoots Actress, And Then Commits Suicide

title: War Comes to Guernsey Street

body: It seemed like a fair price to Streeter Nelson, a financial adviser from Pittsburgh: $2,900 to move half a houseful of her possessions to Rhode Island. title: Movers Go on Trial in an Extortion Case

body: In September 2002, The New York Times ceased regular publication of Portraits of Grief, the sketches of those who died in the Sept. 11, 2001, attack on the World Trade Center. Since then, however, some additional surviving families have chosen to provide information. These portraits are based on their recollections. LEON SMITH JR. Big-Hearted
title: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; A Driver With Size 15 Boots, a Stealth Joker and a Spiritual Diner

body: Within less than two hours yesterday morning, two men were killed in separate shootings in Queens and Brooklyn, one at a bodega and the other at a deli. In a third shooting, an employee of a Brooklyn supermarket was shot to death last night by a fellow employe, the police said. John Freddy, 43, was shot at 7 a.m. at the Central Mini Market, at
title: 3 Killed in Separate Shootings In Stores in Brooklyn and Queens

title: For a Stretch of Brooklyn Waterfront, Many Dreams Are Contenders

body: Like the city they serve, MetroCard machines are multilingual. They all display English and Spanish, as well as two other languages chosen from several already programmed in: Chinese, Russian, Korean, Italian, French and Japanese. But City Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. noticed that yet another language of the city, Greek, was not available at the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ASTORIA; MetroCard Machines, Already Fluent In 8 Languages, Add to Their Roster

author: Valerie Gladstone's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about Ronald K. Brown's choreography for ''Crowns.''
body: THE choreographer Elizabeth Streb's new dance center in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is intended to beckon the curious passerby. The one-story brick building, once occupied by the Dutch Mustard Company, has 5,000 square feet of unobstructed space, a 27-foot ceiling and a large sliding door on the front. ''This place will be like an urban barn,'' said
title: DANCE; Leaping Into Brooklyn Saying, 'Let's Be Neighbors'

body: It has not been so very long since New York was a city where, it was said, if you were killed on the street, people would just step over you and keep walking and where the police were more likely to be seen seen as intruders rather than protectors. In some neighborhoods there is less psychological distance from those times than others. Still, it
title: Little Real Outrage Over a Thinner Blue Line

body: AS NEW YORK confronts momentous questions -- about the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan, its budget woes, the danger of terrorism, the prospect of the Olympics in 2012 -- there is no shortage of predictions on where the city is headed in the next few decades. To peer into the future, the City section has consulted a dozen historians, sociologists,
title: New York's Tomorrow: 12 Visions

body: Forget those sweatshirts that say ''Brooklyn,'' or, even worse, ''New York.'' Michael de Zayas is here to help you announce to the world through your sweatshirt that you are from one particular neighborhood, one street or, if you want to get really specific, one address. Mr. de Zayas, 28, is the president and sole employee of Neighborhoodies, a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK GARB; Your 'Hood on Your Chest, Your Heart on Your Sleeve
